title: Will Robinhood receive a Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) before 1 October 2021 related to trading limits imposed on 28 January 2021?
preds: I agree with @johnwallaceone about the short time horizon, but I can see the SEC striking while the iron's hot and piling on with Congress and the various FINRA actions to try to kill the company. SEC hates change and new technology, especially if it means millions of unsophisticated investors get to gamble in the stock market and manipulate stock prices en masse, which is what happened with GME. And while I tend to agree with @Ryan-Beck about the legality of of the trading limits, I can see the trading limits being used as a way to effectively issue a subpoena for everything that Robinhood is doing in their operations (not just what's available via standard regulatory recordkeeping relative to 28 Jan or GME).
A longer time frame would tempt me. The SEC's wheels move slowly.
Agree with @Ryan-Beck 's assessment that they probably didn't do anything in violation of the rules, but staying at 2% since I'm not an expert.
Wall Street if the money-blood of politicians, so a few will be vocal, and those who collect the money in both parties will stop any effort to reign the hustle.
No. Highly unlikely. because such a move would disincentivize all millenials using phone apps for investing.

This seems like a speedy timeline, especially when you consider the fact that Gary Gensler has not hopped into his seat as SEC Chair yet. (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/gary-gensler-sec-chairman/).  A couple other factors also weigh against this happening before 1 October 2021.
>Some of the key pieces of Gensler's agenda include climate change and Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) related regulation.  The SEC recently put together a commission on these topics and Gensler may want to be pro-active on his agenda.  
>Pay for order flow and that impact on retail investors seems more of a concern for the SEC.  The SEC filed an order against Robinhood in December of 2020 related to information on payment for order flow and best-execution requirements. https://www.sec.gov/litigation/admin/2020/33-10906.pdf
>The Robinhood story may be more Net Capital requirements vs nefarious actors (https://techcrunch.com/2021/01/28/the-somewhat-boring-reason-it-appears-that-robinhood-yanked-trading-on-some-securities/). Capital requirements are one of the key pieces of Dodd-Frank. Regulators wanted more transparency and assurance that margin calls could be met and there were not large losses that made waves across the market. Emphasis on capital requirements is even more relevant after the collapse of Archegos Capital for failing to meet margin calls. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archegos_Capital_Management). It seems counterintuitive for a regulator to punish an entity for following regulations.  
>Unless there is clear evidence (e.g., a message from a trader)that Robinhood was halting trading to influence the price, the SEC would most likely not send a Wells notice to Robinhood based on this timeline.

This may not be “textbook” market manipulation but the occurrence definitely was. They also will likely send intent to file charges to get Robinhood to codify their business so the markets and their customers are not blindsided. Really they would rather apps like this be less of a volatile force on the market.
I wonder if any of the Robinhood investors were foreign government unregistered agents?

Robinhood’s decision to halt trading on the 28th of January 2021 as the GameStop trading was on its heat, certainly pissed off a lot of investors. However, given the fact that Robinhood is operating by covering/insuring the investors’ stock purchases, this made it very difficult from a liquidity perspective for the company. I believe Robinhood is having solid ground here in defending their stance, thus the low possibility of receiving a Wells notice.

Started at 10% based on the fact that it's pretty clear that the DTCC was at "fault" for the trading limits, not Robinhood (though I hesitate to blame them for trying to mitigate risk in a trading environment as rife with groupthink on both sides as the WSB vs short HFs GME tug of war was). If they get a Wells notice it'll be purely for, as congressman Bill Huizenga put it in the hearing a few weeks ago, "political theater," and I think the political calculus depends on public sentiment. Seeing as my friends who were screaming about conspiracies in the discord a month ago have forgotten about it and are still gambling on Robinhood everyday, I think the political benefits of roasting Robinhood on tv and twitter are swiftly declining. That said, for every AOC tweet containing the word Robinhood I'll be raising this forecast by 10% (only half-joking). -2.5% because Robinhood just settled charges related to payment for order flow in December, AND this question specifically asks about a wells notice related to trading limits, NOT payment for order flow -2.5% because I can't tell how this question is going to be resolved? As far as I can tell companies aren't legally required to disclose the receipt of Wells notices, nor does the SEC release them publicly. Presumably we'd hear about it in the news, but there's also a chance that Robinhood could get the wells notice and it wouldn't publicly be announced.  Currently at 5% for yes and honestly I think I'm being cautious.
Immediately dropping 40% to 25% after seeing public sentiment.

First forecast, gut feeling. On the fence, I don't see Robinhood receiving much in the way of legal repremending for the activities that took place in January. If they get strung up as the scapegoats, then the public will probably riot for other larger cats to take a hit. Seems politically not ideal. While Robinhood's popularity has sunken, I dont imagine its to a point where the public want their heads.

As furious as Robinhood users are over Robinhood's restriction of trading, this, by itself doesn't seem illegal. To date, we are not aware of any coordination, conspiracy, or accommodation between Robinhood and major short sellers. But .....there will be email trails or tweets that will be examined. A Wells letter means the gov't is intending to actually bring formal charges. That's a big deal and not frivolously invoked. How many times have we seen companies/people profess innocence, but real investigations reveal real transgressions. Without public revelations of accommodations etc., it would seem forecast should be lower, but  CYA seems prudent.
Everyone should play by the same rules and if this were to happen especially in a Democratic majority govt they better be ready for more changes.
I don't think Robinhood did anything in violation of the rules, their trading halt was due to collateral requirements. So I expect mostly bluster from Congress but nothing official from a regulator.

I think it is very likely that the SEC will open an investigation into the overall practices at Robinhood...I would put that closer to 100%.  I do not know the intricacies of brokerages imposing trading limits, so I tempered my estimate to 75% specifically related to the trading limits.

With thanks to @halseyj123 and @Dustin-MacDonald, to the reference material, the likelihood is low due to the slowness of these bodies to act and as has been reported on the wall street crash - the influence and underlying relationships may have been the drivers for this to occur and quietly allowed to occur (purely speculative).

Public disclosure of Wells notices are not required (see Richman v. Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., et al., No. 1:10-cv-03461-PAC, slip op. (S.D.N.Y. June 21, 2012))
- With this in mind it is difficult to establish an outside view (come up with a base rate)  Robinhood and many other smaller brokerages (that lacked robust balance sheets) elected to restrict buy orders on a short list of "meme stocks." Robinhood claims this decision was spurred by a hefty increase in the margin requirements posted by the DTCC (semi-governmental organization / clearinghouse that all the brokerages  use to settle trades). Robinhood did not have the liquidity to meet the requirements of the clearinghouse, so they had no other option but to restrict buy orders.  https://nysba.org/what-is-the-sec-going-to-do-about-gamestop/
This article suggests that the SEC would only go after Robinhood if there were some ulterior motive for manipulating markets (e.g. some relationship with Citadel or Melvin Capital). This claim seems to be an overblown conspiracy theory IMO. There were a number of brokerages that made the same decisions as Robinhood, which suggests to me there is some systemic cause (e.g. the central clearing house raising capital requirements to a level that small brokerages cannot afford). For these reasons, I believe it is highly unlikely for Robinhood to receive a Wells Notice before October 1, 2021.

Wells Notices are sent out pretty slowly. The SEC has to complete an investigation in order to begin the Wells process. That means that it tends to be 1+ years for the investigation and then another 6-12 months before a Wells notice is received. I'm open to information from experts about whether the SEC ever speeds these things up but I imagine they're not going to prioritize Robinhood over any other. Edit: http://www.wlrk.com/webdocs/wlrknew/AttorneyPubs/WLRK.25580.17.pdf See page 8 of this PDF, the Wells notice precedes enforcement action around 6 months at the latest, although extensions are possible.
